prohibitedSubstances.title: 1. Prohibited Substances and Methods
prohibitedSubstances.description: According to the Government of India, the use of certain substances and methods in sports is prohibited. These include:
prohibitedSubstances.final: Athletes must ensure that they do not use any prohibited substances or methods as part of their training or competition.

testingProcedures.title: 2. Testing Procedures
testingProcedures.description: Anti-doping tests are conducted to ensure that athletes are not using prohibited substances. The procedures include:
testingProcedures.final: Athletes may be selected for testing at any time and are required to comply with the testing process.

consequences.title: 3. Consequences of Doping Violations
consequences.description: Violations of anti-doping rules can result in severe consequences, including:
consequences.final: It is the responsibility of every athlete to be aware of the anti-doping rules and ensure they are not in violation.

rightsResponsibilities.title: 4. Rights and Responsibilities of Athletes
rightsResponsibilities.description: Athletes have certain rights and responsibilities under the anti-doping regulations, including:
items: The right to request a B sample analysis
The right to a fair hearing
The responsibility to remain informed about the anti-doping regulations
The responsibility to avoid prohibited substances and methods
rightsResponsibilities.final: Athletes must comply with all anti-doping regulations to maintain the integrity of the sport.

educationalResources.title: 5. Educational Resources
educationalResources.description: The Government of India provides various educational resources for athletes to stay informed about anti-doping rules. These include:
items: Guidance from coaches and sports authorities
educationalResources.final: Athletes are encouraged to take advantage of these resources to ensure they are fully aware of their obligations under the anti-doping regulations.
